deliberation: Considered whether this standard prophetic formula is purely formulaic or still figurative. The phrase depicts the abstract 'word' as an agent that can come to the prophet, which is a conventional personification / metaphor for prophetic revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: initiates contact, arrives from outside, is experienced as an event
posture: presents revelation as an objective, invasive event beyond the prophet's control
instances.explanation: The abstract divine message is portrayed as a concrete agent that 'comes' to the prophet, personifying the 'word' and metaphorically framing revelation as an invasion or arrival.

deliberation: Looked for metaphor, merism, and personification. Found (1) the 'end/doom' portrayed as coming upon them, and (2) the idiomatic 'four corners of the land' depicting the land as a four-cornered object, a meristic/synecdochic way of saying the whole land.

instances.english_text: Doom! Doom is coming
target: the time of judgment upon Israel
vehicle: an approaching entity that comes upon someone
ground: advances toward a target, cannot be stopped, overwhelms the recipient
posture: portrays judgment as an active attacker, heightening threat and inevitability
instances.explanation: The abstract 'end/doom' is personified as something that comes upon the land like an invading force, rather than a mere point in time.

instances.english_text: upon the four corners of the land
target: the entirety of the land/territory of Israel
vehicle: a flat object with four corners (e.g., cloth/map)
ground: has extremities or outer limits, can be covered completely
using edges/corners to denote total area
posture: uses an idiomatic merism/synecdoche to stress that no part of the land will escape
instances.explanation: The land is conceptualized as a four‑cornered object; mentioning its 'four corners' is a figurative, idiomatic way of saying 'everywhere in the land' (meristic/synecdochic metaphor).

deliberation: Examined anger language and 'ways'. Found (1) idiomatic/metonymic 'I will send my nose/anger against you', and (2) the recurring biblical metaphor of 'ways' for moral conduct.

instances.english_text: I will let loose My anger against you
ground: comes forcefully against a target, causes harm, is directed and intentional
posture: presents anger as an actively launched force, intensifying the threat of judgment
instances.explanation: Hebrew 'nose' (אַף) stands metonymically for anger, and this anger is depicted as something that can be 'sent' against people, blending metonymy with martial metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will judge you according to your ways
ground: develops over time, has direction, can be straight or twisted, leads to destinations
posture: frames behavior as a chosen path with consequences, reinforcing responsibility for their 'route'
instances.explanation: The common biblical metaphor of life conduct as 'ways/paths' is used: Israel's behaviors are pictured as routes they walk, by which they will be judged.

deliberation: Checked for repeated motifs: 'eye will not spare' and 'ways'. Found (1) 'my eye will not pity' as an idiomatic metonymy for compassion, and (2) the same 'ways' = conduct metaphor as in v.3.

instances.english_text: I will show you no pity (literally: my eye will not spare you)
target: God's decision not to show compassion
vehicle: an eye that does or does not 'spare'
organ of sight as agent of pity
human face/eye as seat of emotion
ground: the eye's look can signal favor or disfavor, attention or disregard
posture: stresses the complete withdrawal of compassionate regard from the people
instances.explanation: The 'eye' stands metonymically for compassionate regard; saying 'my eye will not spare' figuratively expresses God's refusal to show pity.

instances.english_text: for I will requite you for your ways
ground: chosen and followed over time, lead to specific outcomes, can be straight or crooked
posture: reiterates that their chosen 'paths' bring back corresponding judgment
instances.explanation: Again life-conduct is conceptualized as 'ways'; God gives back to them according to these figurative paths they have walked.

deliberation: Looked for metaphor in the description of disaster. 'A disaster is coming' portrays the calamity as an approaching agent rather than an impersonal state.

instances.english_text: A singular disaster; a disaster is coming
ground: moves toward a location, reaches and affects those it comes to
experience of someone/thing coming upon you
posture: casts the disaster as an active invader rather than a passive condition
instances.explanation: The disaster is personified as something that 'comes', giving it the character of an advancing assailant.

deliberation: Noted repetition of 'end/doom' and the verb 'has awakened against you'. This clearly personifies the 'end' as an agent that wakes up and comes at them.

instances.hebrew_text: קֵ֣ץ בָּ֔א בָּ֥א הַקֵּ֖ץ הֵקִ֣יץ אֵלָ֑יִךְ
instances.english_text: Doom is coming! The hour of doom is coming! It stirs (has awakened) against you
vehicle: a sleeper who awakens and rises against someone
ground: was latent, then becomes active and confrontational, turns against a victim
posture: stresses that what was long warned of is now fully active and turned aggressively upon them
instances.explanation: The 'end' is depicted as having 'awakened' and come against them, personifying the time of judgment as a hostile, aroused foe.

deliberation: The text speaks of 'the cycle/morning/doom has come upon you', 'the time has come; the day is near'. These temporal realities are treated as approaching entities. The contrast 'panic on the mountains, not echo of joy' is largely literal description of emotional atmosphere. I treat the main figure as personification of time/doom.

instances.hebrew_text: בָּ֧אָה הַצְּפִירָ֛ה אֵלֶ֖יךָ יוֹשֵׁ֣ב הָאָ֑רֶץ בָּ֣א הָעֵ֗ת קָר֛וֹב הַיּ֥וֹם
instances.english_text: The cycle (doom/morning) has come around for you, O inhabitants of the land; the time has come; the day is near
target: the appointed time of judgment on the land
historical turning point under God's decree
vehicle: a person or event that comes near to someone
ground: draws closer, finally arrives, confronts those it comes to
posture: underscores inevitability and immanence of the judgment moment
instances.explanation: The 'cycle/time/day' of judgment is personified as something that comes to the inhabitants, as if an approaching visitor/occasion.

deliberation: Identified (1) 'pour out my wrath' as a standard anger-as-liquid metaphor, and (2) 'finish/consume my nose (anger) in you' employing 'nose' metonymically for anger.

instances.english_text: Very soon I will pour out My wrath upon you
ground: comes forth in a stream, overwhelms and covers, is no longer contained
posture: depicts wrath as an overwhelming, unrestrained outpouring, intensifying its severity
experiential imagery of being inundated by judgment
instances.explanation: Wrath is metaphorically construed as a liquid that God can 'pour out' on the people, emphasizing its overwhelming and unrestrained character.

instances.english_text: and spend My anger on you (literally: I will finish my nose in you)
target: the exercise and exhaustion of God's anger
vehicle: 'nose' (אַף) as anger that can be used up
limited resource or store to be consumed
ground: can be diminished and brought to an end through action
posture: communicates that the full measure of anger will be expended in judgment
closure of patience / completion of retribution
instances.explanation: Using 'nose' metonymically for anger, the verse speaks of 'finishing' it, conceptualizing anger as a consumable resource to be fully spent in judgment.

deliberation: Again checked 'eye will not spare' and 'ways'. Both repeat earlier figurative patterns: eye = compassion (metonymic idiom) and ways = moral conduct (path metaphor).

instances.english_text: I will show you no pity and no compassion (literally: my eye will not spare, nor will I have compassion)
vehicle: an eye that does or does not spare
facial orientation as sign of attitude
ground: visual attention reflects inward stance, can indicate mercy or its absence
posture: stresses the total removal of benevolent regard
instances.explanation: The 'eye' stands for compassionate regard; saying it will not 'spare' personifies the eye and figuratively expresses God’s unpitying stance.

instances.english_text: I will requite you for your ways
ground: chosen direction, reveals character, leads to specific outcomes
posture: reiterates retributive logic using the journey metaphor
correspondence between path chosen and end received
instances.explanation: Again, their life-conduct is figuratively cast as 'ways'; judgment is framed as giving them the consequences of those paths.

deliberation: Saw a cluster of images: (1) 'the cycle/doom has come out' (personification), (2) 'the rod has blossomed', and (3) 'arrogance has budded'—an extended growth metaphor applied to judgment and pride. Treated these as three distinct expressions within one extended image.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּ֥ה הַיּ֖וֹם הִנֵּ֣ה בָאָ֑ה יָֽצְאָה֙ הַצְּפִרָ֔ה
instances.english_text: Here is the day! See, the cycle has come round; it has appeared
vehicle: something that 'comes out' and becomes visible
ground: hidden or anticipated beforehand, then publicly appears
posture: frames the judgment day as a concrete, emerging reality, not an abstract date
instances.explanation: The 'day/cycle' of doom is personified as something that has 'come out' and become visible, as if stepping onto the stage.

instances.english_text: The rod has blossomed
target: the fully developed instrument of judgment (oppressors/violence)
vehicle: a rod that sprouts/blossoms like a plant
ground: starts small and then reaches full development, ready for use
maturation from latent to mature state
posture: conveys that the instrument of judgment has reached full potency
completion of preparatory phase of judgment
instances.explanation: The 'rod'—symbol of discipline or oppressor—is portrayed as a plant that has blossomed, metaphorically expressing its full development as a tool of judgment.

instances.english_text: arrogance has budded
target: inner moral state of the people
ground: begins unseen, then emerges and displays itself openly
development from hidden root to visible bloom
posture: depicts arrogance as something that has grown to conspicuous, ripe expression, warranting judgment
instances.explanation: Arrogance is metaphorically described as a plant that has budded, conveying that their pride has reached a visible, developed stage.

deliberation: The key figure is 'violence has risen into a rod of wickedness'—a clear metaphor where an abstract habit (violence) is portrayed as a physical rod used for punishment.

instances.english_text: lawlessness (violence) has grown into a rod of wickedness
vehicle: a 'rod of wickedness' that rises up
ground: inflicts harm, dominates and crushes victims, stands over the weak
posture: presents their own violence as the very instrument of their punishment, highlighting poetic justice
instances.explanation: Abstract 'violence' is personified and metaphorically depicted as rising up as a 'rod'—an implement of wicked aggression and eventual chastisement.

deliberation: Looked for figures in economic language. 'The time has come, the day has arrived' uses temporal entities as if they move/arrive. Buyer and seller reactions are literal. I treat the arrival of time/day as personification.

instances.english_text: The time has come, the day has arrived
target: the moment of judgment overtaking Jerusalem
ground: draws near and reaches its destination, becomes present to those waiting
human experience of awaited events showing up
posture: underscores that the period forecast by prophecy is now present and inescapable
instances.explanation: Time and 'the day' are personified as entities that 'come' and 'arrive', marking the onset of judgment as an arrival event.

deliberation: Considered whether 'vision shall not return' or legal-economic imagery is figurative. The verse mostly uses straightforward legal/commercial language and prophetic prediction. Any figurativeness in 'vision' is standard prophetic usage, not a distinct scenic metaphor here. I treat this verse as essentially literal in expression.

Reviewed trumpet, preparation, and wrath phrases. 'They have sounded the horn' and 'no one goes to battle' are literal within a war context. 'My wrath is against all her multitude' is standard theological wording without a concrete image like 'pour' or 'burn' here. No clearly marked figurative expression distinctive to this verse.

Detected two figures: (1) 'the sword is outside' where 'sword' stands metonymically for war/attacking armies, and (2) famine and pestilence 'shall devour him', personifying these disasters as devouring agents.

instances.english_text: The sword is outside
target: the presence of hostile armies and warfare outside the city
vehicle: a sword as a concrete weapon
ground: kills by cutting, represents armed conflict, inspires fear
posture: compresses the whole reality of invading forces into the image of 'the sword', intensifying the threat
instances.explanation: 'Sword' stands metonymically and metaphorically for warfare/attacking armies at the city’s outskirts.

instances.english_text: famine and pestilence shall devour him
target: those trapped in the besieged city
vehicle: famine and pestilence as devouring eaters
ground: gradually consume and destroy life, leave nothing intact
being 'eaten up' by a hostile force
posture: portrays these calamities as active, voracious enemies, magnifying their horror
instances.explanation: Famine and plague are personified as creatures that 'eat' people, metaphorically expressing how these disasters consume lives.

deliberation: The main figure is an explicit simile: survivors fleeing to the mountains are likened to 'doves of the valleys, all of them moaning'.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָי֣וּ אֶל־הֶהָרִ֗ים כְּיוֹנֵ֧י הַגֵּאָי֛וֹת כֻּלָּ֖ם הֹמ֑וֹת
instances.english_text: they shall take to the mountains; they shall be like doves of the valley, moaning together
target: the terrified human survivors of judgment
vehicle: doves of the valleys that moan/coo plaintively
ground: seek high places for refuge, make continuous mournful sounds, appear timid and vulnerable
shared experiential pattern of helpless lamentation
posture: presents the survivors as pitiable, frightened, and constantly lamenting, not heroic
emphasizes the cost of iniquity on individuals
instances.explanation: A direct simile compares the survivors to doves of the valleys, highlighting their timidity, flight to higher ground, and unceasing moaning.

deliberation: Identified two bodily idioms for terror: (1) 'all hands shall grow weak' and (2) 'all knees shall turn to water'. Both are metaphoric/idiomatic for loss of courage, the second being especially vivid.

instances.english_text: All hands shall grow weak
target: the people's courage and capacity for action
ground: inability to grasp or fight, loss of effective action
posture: depicts total demoralization and incapacity to resist
instances.explanation: Weak hands are an idiomatic metaphor for loss of strength and courage, representing emotional collapse under terror.

instances.english_text: and all knees shall turn to water
ground: no longer able to support weight, shaking and collapsing
experience of legs giving way from terror
posture: hyperbolically conveys utter panic and inability to stand before judgment
instances.explanation: The phrase pictures knees as turning into water, a hyperbolic metaphor for total loss of stability and control caused by fear.

deliberation: Distinguished literal mourning customs (sackcloth, shaved heads) from figurative expressions. Found (1) 'horror shall cover them'—terror as a covering garment, and (2) 'on all faces shame'—shame as a visible covering.

instances.english_text: and horror shall cover them
ground: surrounds and envelops, is visible to others, cannot be easily removed
posture: presents terror as inescapable and all‑encompassing, like clothing wrapped around them
instances.explanation: Horror is metaphorically depicted as a covering placed over them, as if they were clothed or wrapped in terror.

instances.english_text: every face shall [show] shame
target: their sense of disgrace and humiliation
vehicle: shame on faces as if applied or spread over them
ground: shame that is inward becomes outwardly visible, marking one's appearance
manifestation of inner state on the surface
posture: emphasizes that shame will be publicly visible, not hidden
social consequence of sin under judgment
instances.explanation: Shame is portrayed as something that comes onto every face, using the face as the surface on which inner disgrace is visibly displayed.

deliberation: The key figure is calling their silver and gold 'the stumbling block of their iniquity'—wealth conceptualized as an obstacle that trips them into sin.

instances.english_text: Because they made them stumble into guilt (literally: for it was the stumbling block of their iniquity)
target: their silver and gold as morally misused possessions
vehicle: a stumbling block/stone one trips over
ground: causes one to fall, leads to injury/damage when encountered carelessly
posture: frames their wealth as the cause and occasion of their moral downfall
instances.explanation: Their silver and gold are metaphorically labeled 'the stumbling block of their iniquity'—an obstacle causing them to fall into sin.

deliberation: Examined 'beautiful adornments' and their use for idolatrous images. The verse describes literally that they turned their ornaments into idols; the uncleanness is cultic, not metaphorical. No clear additional figurative expression beyond the theological labels 'detestable abominations'.
Checked 'I will give it into the hand of strangers'. Here 'hand' is a classic metonymy for power/control over something. The rest (spoil, plunder, defile) is literal conquest language.

instances.english_text: I will give them into the hand of strangers
ground: what is in one's hand is under one's control or possession
posture: depicts foreign domination vividly as having things placed into their grasp
instances.explanation: The 'hand' of strangers stands metonymically for their power and control; to give something into their hand is figurative for placing it under their dominion.

deliberation: Noted 'I will turn my face from them'—a standard anthropomorphic metaphor where God's favor/presence is conceptualized as his face turned toward someone. The desecration of 'my treasured place' is literal cultic pollution.

instances.english_text: I will turn My face from them
target: withdrawal of God's favor and protective presence
relational stance of God toward Israel
vehicle: a face turned away from someone
physical orientation of a human face
social gesture of disregard or rejection
ground: signals broken relationship, lack of attention, and rejection
posture: expresses divine rejection in relational, personal terms, heightening the pathos
loss of protective presence as judgment
instances.explanation: God is described anthropomorphically as turning his 'face' away, a metaphor for withdrawing his attentive, favorable presence.

deliberation: Considered 'forge the chain' and 'the land/city is full of bloodshed/violence'. The 'full of' expressions are hyperbolic container metaphors, but I chose the dominant figure as the land and city portrayed as containers filled with crime and violence.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֣י הָאָ֗רֶץ מָֽלְאָה֙ מִשְׁפַּ֣ט דָּמִ֔ים וְהָעִ֖יר מָלְאָ֥ה חָמָֽס
instances.english_text: for the land is full of bloody crimes, and the city is full of lawlessness
target: the prevalence of violent injustice in the land and city
vehicle: a container filled to the brim with a substance
ground: no empty space left; content is pervasive throughout
posture: hyperbolically communicates that violence and injustice permeate everything
sets up justification for severe judgment
instances.explanation: The land and city are metaphorically portrayed as containers filled up with 'bloody judgments' and 'violence', a hyperbolic way of saying such crimes are pervasive.

deliberation: Language of bringing in foreign nations, taking houses, stopping the pride of the strong, and defiling sanctuaries is straightforward. 'Pride of the strong' is an abstraction but not built into a concrete image here. No distinct figurative image beyond normal theological abstraction.
The verse personifies 'horror' (or 'terror') as something that 'comes', similar to earlier uses of 'doom' and 'day' coming. Seeking peace/safety is literal desire, not an image.

instances.english_text: Horror comes
target: the overwhelming calamity and dread overtaking the people
ground: moves toward its object and then is present with them
encountering something that comes upon you
posture: casts the horror as an invading reality that overtakes them
instances.explanation: Abstract 'horror/terror' is personified as something that comes upon them, emphasizing its inescapable arrival.

deliberation: Considered repeated 'calamity upon calamity' and 'rumor upon rumor'. This is intensifying repetition, but not built around a concrete metaphor, simile, or image domain; it functions as a rhetorical piling up rather than a distinct figurative mapping. Loss of vision/Torah/counsel is literal prophetic-priestly failure. I treat the verse as without a clear standalone image-metaphor.

Found two figures: (1) 'the prince shall clothe himself with desolation'—devastation as a garment, and (2) 'I will deal with them according to their ways', the recurring path metaphor for conduct. The trembling hands are literal physical reaction to fear.

instances.english_text: the prince shall clothe himself with desolation
target: the prince's experience of utter ruin and grief
vehicle: a garment of desolation that one wears
ground: is visibly worn, defines outward appearance, envelops the person
posture: emphasizes that devastation will be his all-encompassing, visible condition
judgment as total envelopment in ruin
instances.explanation: Desolation is metaphorically treated as clothing that the prince wears, conveying that ruin will be his all‑embracing, outwardly visible state.

instances.english_text: I will treat them according to their ways
target: the people's overall pattern of behavior
ground: chosen direction, shows character, leads to particular ends
posture: reiterates covenantal retribution in terms of the life‑as‑journey metaphor
instances.explanation: As elsewhere, their conduct is portrayed as 'ways'; God responds to them in line with the figurative paths they have chosen.
